The computing power is housed in massive warehouse-like buildings known as data centers. There are economies of scale in the business, meaning the cost per unit gets cheaper as the size increases. For example, this means that for a company like Netflix, the cost to outsource the hosting of its streaming videos to AWS is cheaper than hosting the data in-house.

November 30, 2022, was the widespread launch of ChatGPT. In only 5 days, it hit 1 million users. As of November 2025, monthly active users reached 810 million. Accommodating the growth of ChatGPT, as well as other new AI models such as Claude, Gemini and Grok, has led to massive new capex spending on the part of the hyperscalers. According to Wired:

The amount of capital pouring into AI data center projects is staggering. Last week, Microsoft, Alphabet, Meta, and Amazon reported their 2025 capital expenditures would total roughly $370 billion, and they expect that number to keep rising in 2026. The biggest spender last quarter was Microsoft, which put nearly $35 billion into data centers and other investments, equivalent to 45 percent of its revenue.
Rarely, if ever, has a single technology absorbed this much money this quickly. Warnings of an AI bubble are getting louder every day, but whether or not a crash eventually happens, the frenzy is already reshaping the US economy. Harvard economist Jason Furman estimates that investment in data centers and software processing technology accounted for nearly all of US GDP growth in the first half of 2025.

Where:

This information is reported in each company's cash flow statement under investing activities. For example:
In its quarter ended September 30, 2025, Microsoft reported Additions to property and equipment of $-19.394 billion with no separate entry for inflows from disposals. Thus, its capex for the quarter was $19.394 billion.
In its quarter ended September 30, 2025, Alphabet reported Purchases of property and equipment of $-23.953 billion and no separate entry for inflows from disposals. Its capex was $23.953 billion. 
In its quarter ended September 30, 2025, Amazon reported Purchases of property and equipment of $-35.095 billion and Proceeds from property and equipment sales and incentives of $867 million. Adding the numbers and multiplying by -1 equals capex of $34.228 billion.
The combined capex for the quarter ended September 30, 2025 was therefore $77.575 billion.

question_title: Will Nvidia's stock price reach a new record close in February 2026?
background:
Nvidia dominates the AI chip market, with 70-95% market share depending on how it is measured. As such, it has been the poster boy of the AI boom. Microsoft spends a full 47% of its capital expenditures on Nvidia chips, Amazon 11%, Meta 25%, Alphabet 15% and Tesla 13%. Many big tech companies also rent data centers from CoreWeave, which itself spends billions on Nvidia chips. 
In the year through December 3, 2025, Nvidia’s stock price was up 30%. During that period, the trailing month's closing high averaged 19% higher than the trailing month's closing low.
Nvidia’s business has been firing on all cylinders, selling every one of its flagship Blackwell chips it can make, and with demand projected by analysts to exceed supply well into fiscal year 2026. However, new business challenges have presented themselves. First, Nvidia faces massive uncertainty in China, with the US in November 2025 announcing restrictions on sales of scaled-down Nvidia chips to the country, while China itself has banned Nvidia chips from new data centers. Secondly, Google is ramping up its Ironwood TPU chips, which compete favorably on many metrics with Blackwell.
Twenty-six years of Nvidia's stock price history is available from MacroTrends. The highest close price NVDA has ever reached was 207.03 on October 29, 2025.

question_title: What will be the Indian Wholesale Price Index monthly inflation rate in January 2026?
background:

In 2025, India saw a dramatic drop in wholesale inflation, even entering deflation in the latter half of the year, with a substantial drop in food prices being one of the most significant factors.
The provisional January figure is expected to be released on February 16, 2026.
resolution_criteria: This question will resolve as the Indian Wholesale Price Index monthly inflation rate for January 2026 for All Commodities.

100 \times \bigg( \frac{WPI_{Jan2026}}{WPI_{Dec2025}} - 1 \bigg) \%

The provisional figure first published for January 2026 will be used and compared to the figure for December 2025 included in that release, later updates or revisions are immaterial

question_title: Will the German 10-Year Bond Yield move by 20bps or more during February 2026?
background:
Bonds are a type of loan in which the issuer must pay out a percent of the total value at regular intervals before repaying the full value at a set date. Governments often issue bonds to finance debt and in turn these bonds are then resold on the open market at a floating rate.
The 10-Year Bond Yield is typically considered the benchmark of any government's long term borrowing costs. Higher values generally indicate expectations of higher economic growth but also can indicate a lack of confidence in the lender's ability to repay its loans.
During 2025, Germany dramatically increased military spending, creating an exception to the strict debt brake, allowing the increase to be financed through debt. 
Although increasing debt generally leads to higher yields, it has also led to more liquidity in the historically tight market. The German government has in turn attempted to position German bonds as a safe and stable alternative to U.S. Treasury bonds, following declining confidence in the U.S. government bond market.
resolution_criteria: This question will resolve as Yes if, for any day during February 2026, the daily yield of the German 10-Year Federal Bond is at least 20 basis points higher or lower than the daily yield for January 30, 2026.
fine_print: The resolution source for this question will be official data from the Deutsche Bundesbank.

question_title: What will be the highest price of gold per troy ounce in February 2026?
background:
Through December 19, 2025, when its 100-day futures contracts closed at 4,387.0, gold was up 67% year-to-date, on a pace to be a record-setting year for the metal. By contrast the S&P 500 was up 17.66% YTD, with dividends included.
A spreadsheet with the history of prices from August 30, 2000 to December 19, 2025 can be found here. 
Gold, a rare metal both on earth and throughout the universe, has been widely used throughout human history both as a medium of exchange and as a store of reserve value. Where gold comes from is actually unknown, with the prevailing theory being that it is ejected from explosions of a certain highly magnetized type of neutron star called a magnetar.
Ray Dalio, founder of Bridgewater Associates, has explained the long-term value of gold as follows: 
Gold has also been a favored money because it has lower confiscation risks than other monies and other assets. That’s because it doesn’t depend on getting money from someone, and it’s tougher for someone or some government to take it from you. It is the toughest money to grab because it can be held in one’s own secure possession, unlike all other monies that require others to make payments of money to give them value. It can’t be stolen in cyberattacks. For this reason, gold has been the favored asset when there were big risks of money confiscations due to a) financial crises that led to very high taxes and other confiscatory policies and/or b) economic and monetary wars between countries (e.g., sanctions).
As a result, during times when there were monetary/debt crises and/or wars that increased the risks of confiscation, gold went up a lot in value (or, said more accurately, it was the money that didn’t fall in value). This is why gold has continued to be the most fundamental money over time, with the best track record of having its value keep pace with the cost of living over very long periods of time.
Dalio's recent interview with Bloomberg's Lisa Abramowicz.

question_title: What will be the U.S. Dollar to Argentine Peso exchange rate on March 2, 2026?
background:
For decades, Argentina has struggled with inflation, with particularly high rates during recent years. Argentina's government has historically kept the value of the peso artificially high through a government set exchange rate. In 2023, Argentine voters elected Javier Milei to the presidency, on a platform that included extreme economic reforms. Once in office, one of Milei's first actions was to cut the official value of the Argentine peso in half.
Inflation soared higher for the first few months of Milei's presidency, peaking in April 2024, before beginning a descent, that would eventually bring Argentina's inflation rate to its lowest level in years. Although the inflation rate has started to trend upward again, it remains low by recent standards.
The peso has however continued to lose value against the dollar. When Milei took office, one U.S. dollar cost 366 pesos. At the beginning of his "shock therapy" program, the figure was dramatically increased to 800 pesos. By April 2024, the exchange rate was Arg$861; by April 2025, Arg$1,074.
On April 11, 2025, Argentina adopted an exchange rate band regime, in which the central bank would aim to keep the exchange rate between Arg$1,000 and Arg$1,400, by buying and selling pesos as necessary to control the currency's value. For the rest of 2025, the exchange rate continued to increase, exceeding 1,400 for much of the last few months. Then on December 15, 2025, the BCRA announced that the currency bands would themselves begin to be adjusted upward.
As of January 23, 2026, the closing exchange rate was 1,429.2451 pesos per U.S. dollar, with the exchange rate band currently having an upper limit of 1,543.7100 and a lower limit of 905.8600.
resolution_criteria: This question will resolve as the exchange rate of the U.S. dollar to Argentine pesos, on March 2, 2026, as reported on the Close column of the corresponding Yahoo! Finance page.

question_title: How much higher will the Shanghai–LA spot container freight rate be than the Shanghai–Rotterdam rate on March 5, 2026?
background:
The Drewry World Container Index (WCI) is a weekly series that reports spot container freight rates for major east–west trade lanes. It consists of route-specific indices plus a composite index, and is quoted in US dollars per 40-foot container (FEU).
In the WCI methodology, the “agreed freight rate” is intended to reflect the total ocean freight including bunker adjustment and other applicable surcharges, and terminal handling charges where commonly included by market practice, while excluding inland transportation-related surcharges. “Spot” in this context denotes short-term market pricing that can change rapidly with capacity and demand conditions, as opposed to longer-duration contract rates.
Drewry publishes weekly index values for Shanghai-Los Angeles, Shanghai-New York, Shanghai-Genoa, and Shanghai-Rotterdam
Container shipping rates from Shanghai fell steadily in early 2025, spiked sharply in late May–June, then declined through autumn before a modest recovery toward early 2026, with Shanghai–Los Angeles consistently priced above Shanghai–Rotterdam.
Although all prices reflect global container market conditions, each is also sensitive to lane-specific operational factors. Since late 2023, a prominent driver for Asia-Europe pricing has been the Red Sea security disruption, which led many carriers to reroute voyages around the Cape of Good Hope, increasing sailing distance and vessel time requirements. 
By January 2026, some major carriers began resuming Red Sea and Suez transits on certain services as security conditions appeared to improve, which analysts noted could reduce transit times and put downward pressure on freight rates
resolution_criteria: This question will resolve as the value of the Drewry World Container Index for the Shanghai to Los Angeles route minus the value for the Shanghai to Rotterdam route on March 5, 2026.
fine_print:
This question will resolve as the values for March 5 when accessed first by Metaculus on or after March 6. Further revisions will not cause this question to re-resolve.
If the price for Shanghai to Rotterdam is higher than the price for Shanghai to Los Angeles, this question will resolve as a negative number.
In the event data is released for a different day that week besides March 5 and is not available for March 5, Metaculus may use data for the nearest day between March 1 and March 7, inclusive, to resolve the question, using the later figure if there are two equally distant days released. If Drewry does not report the required data before March 14, 2026, this question will be annulled.

question_title: Will the United States impose additional sanctions on Russia related to the Ukraine war before March 14, 2026?
background:

(The US ultimately imposed multiple rounds of sanctions related to that conflict.) And in December 2016, President Obama imposed additional sanctions on Russia in connection with the country's alleged interference in the 2016 US elections.
In 2017, Donald Trump came to power, taking a notably more conciliatory approach toward Russia than his predecessor had. Nevertheless, in July 2017, Congress passed the Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act, which imposed new sanctions on Russia for its activities relating to Ukraine, Syria, and the 2016 election. Though he criticized the legislation as flawed, President Trump signed it into law. The Trump administration subsequently imposed numerous other sanctions relating to Russia.
In February 2022, Russia invaded Ukraine, triggering "the most severe economic sanctions ever levied on Russia." And as that conflict drags on, sanctions remain a key component of US foreign policy vis-à-vis Russia. On December 17, 2025, Reuters reported that the Trump administration was preparing an additional round of sanctions on Russia to pressure it to negotiate a peace with Ukraine.
resolution_criteria:
This question will resolve as Yes if, after January 12, 2026 and before March 14, 2026 ET, the US government announces via binding legal action a new or expanded sanctions-related restriction on Russian persons or entities and the official announcement explicitly states it is related to the Ukraine war.

fine_print: An example of an action that would count is OFAC's October 22, 2025 issuance of new sanctions targeting Russian oil companies (including Lukoil and Rosneft), with the accompanying press release stating that it is doing so "as a result of Russia’s lack of serious commitment to a peace process to end the war in Ukraine."

question_title: Will any NVIDIA GPUs better than the H200 be allowed to be exported to China before March 14, 2026?
background:
In October 2022, the US Department of Commerce enacted export controls to limit the People's Republic of China's access to advanced computing chips and semiconductors, citing national security and foreign policy concerns. Initially, these rules were not aimed at restricting China's capacity to train large language models. However, they directly restricted the class of high-end GPUs that subsequently became central to generative AI, leading to an eventual shift in the controls' focus to encompass such issues.
In response to these restrictions, NVIDIA repeatedly designed China-specific variants of its chips that complied with the export controls. These initially included the A800 and H800 chips, which were later banned after an update to the export regulations, and then the H20, which was only briefly restricted in early 2025. In late 2025, reporting indicated the US planned to block a new, highly capable China-specific chip referred to as B30A. Subsequently, however, President Trump announced, in a policy shift, that the US would permit exports of the powerful H200 chip to China, subject to a 25% fee.
resolution_criteria:
This question will resolve as Yes if, after January 12, 2026 and before March 14, 2026 ET, the US government publicly states that it will permit any Nvidia GPU that is better than the H200 to be exported to mainland China.
This question will also resolve as Yes if such GPUs are directly exported to mainland China, without credible sources reporting that the export violated US export controls or that the US government is taking enforcement action relating to those exports, before March 14, 2026 ET.
For the purposes of this question, "better than H200" is defined as any GPU with both:
a peak FP8 Tensor Core throughput (including sparsity) higher than 4 petaFLOPS
and
an HBM bandwidth of at least 4.8 TB/s.
fine_print:
"The US government publicly states" includes a statement by the sitting US President on a personally controlled account (e.g., Truth Social) that is treated as credible, even if no agency issues a formal notice.
Statements that indicate that exports will be permitted in the future have to include a specific date within 2026. Vague time periods (e.g. "in a few months") do not qualify.
Statements that do not clearly indicate exports will be permitted (e.g., “considering,” “discussing,” “investigating”) do not count.

Monthly CPI and core CPI inflation show high volatility in the 1970s–early 1980s and during major shocks such as 2008 and 2020, but are generally lower and more stable in recent decades, with modest month-to-month changes by 2024–2025.
